data.title: ACKNOWLEDGE
questions: In this phase, face the conflict, its impacts and your next move…
To what extent have you clarified the conflict in your mind?
What’s actually in conflict with the other person/party?
How exactly is the situation impacting you? Your group?
What’s at stake if not resolved? Or resolved unsatisfactorily?
What’s the potential downside or risk of raising the issue?
To what extent have you communicated your issue with them?
If not, what seems to be hindering you from communicating it?
How do you think they perceive the issue? How do you know?
What common goal, purpose or interest do you share with them?
Why would collaborating toward a joint solution be in their interest?
How and when would you propose meeting to discuss this?
What ground rules would be important at this meeting?
Convene the meeting with jointly developed ground rules.

data.title: UNDERSTAND
questions: In this phase, seek to fully understand the other before defining the conflict…
To what extent do you understand the other party’s needs?
What are their interests in this situation? What do they have at stake?
How can you understand how they perceive the situation?
How can you build trust with them so they openly share their interests and needs?
How will you communicate your interests and needs to them?
How do you ensure your data is specific and verifiable? And theirs?
How will you reach agreement on what important words/terms mean?
How will you challenge any misperceptions, assumptions or perceived biases?
How will you create a space where both parties feel comfortable being transparent?
Ask questions that focus on each other’s interests, needs and concerns—not positions.
Above all, LISTEN. To understand—not to judge. To ALL of their message.
The test of full understanding: each party states the other's case to their satisfaction.

data.title: DEFINE
questions: In this phase, jointly define what the conflict is, and frame it as a question.
Take turns discussing what the difference or disagreement is really about.
What essentially is the ‘problem’? What’s at issue here?
Jointly define the conflict as a decision or problem to be solved.
Jointly frame the conflict in the form of a question…very specifically.
Ensure both parties agree on the question as worded, and post it.

data.title: SEARCH
questions: In this phase, jointly explore all possible ways of answering the question and resolving the conflict.
Brainstorm ways to answer the question posted.
Jointly set and respect ground rules for brainstorming
Suspend judgment in developing ideas and possible solutions.
Be willing to let go of what you thought the ultimate solution would be.
Look for hybrid solutions or ways to combine answers or approaches.

data.title: AGREE + COMMIT
questions: In this phase, jointly reach agreement on how to address the conflict, and implement it.
Identify (perhaps through voting) the three best proposals.
Evaluate each proposed resolution against both parties’ interests/needs.
Find common ground, and reach consensus on a mutually-agreeable solution.
Share openly what you like about the resolution, and any lingering concerns.
Ask everyone to either 1) agree and support; 2) support with reservations; or 3) decline support.
If anyone declines to support, require them to share how their concerns could be resolved.
Discuss and incorporate concerns until everyone can agree and/or support the decision.
Based on everyone’s commitment to a solution, jointly define a plan of action.
Identify who will do what by when, and how you will monitor/follow-up.
Shake hands, and have each person/party verbally commit to the resolution.
Hold each person accountable for following through on their commitment.
